title-group.article-title: Benchmarking of triaxial failure criteria for composite laminates: Comparison between models of ‘Part (A)’ of ‘WWFE-II’

author-notes.corresp: AS Kaddour, QinetiQ, Farnborough, Hampshire, GU14 0LX, UK Email: askaddour@qinetiq.com

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue: Evaluation of Theories for Predicting Failure in Polymer Composite Laminates Under 3-D States of Stress: Part A of the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-II)

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: As a part of the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise, the originators (or their collaborators) of three-dimensional failure theories applied their methods to 12 carefully selected challenging problems (test cases). In this article, the ‘blind’ theoretical predictions from 12 failure theories, making the backbone of Part (A) of the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise, are compiled in a structured manner. Key features in each theory are identified including: types of failure models employed, whether linear or nonlinear analysis was carried out, reliance on software and numerical methods, allowance for thermal stresses and identification of modes of failure. The results (failure envelopes and stress–strain curves) have been superimposed to show similarities and differences between the predictions of the various theories. In addition, bar charts have been constructed to demonstrate the levels of agreement between the predicted failure stresses and strains. Sources of differences between the predictions of the various three-dimensional failure theories are discussed. Further publications are planned in Part B in which comparison will be made between the predictions described here and the experimental results.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The need to challenge and expose the strengths and weaknesses of contemporary failure criteria for fibre reinforced polymer composites, and to refine and extend their applicability is considered to be crucial for establishing firm, well-founded steps toward obtaining reliable and mature design methodologies. Such methodologies vital in maintaining the competitiveness of the manufacturing industry and its supply chain partners such as software vendors and R&D groups. In particular, they can be used as building blocks for developing numerical or analytical tools for ‘virtual testing’ for composite structures. In it, a designer aims at obtaining optimal shape, weight and cost of a component or an assembly without resorting to the traditional but slow and expensive of ‘make and test’.

Commercial software and computer codes usually contain a large number of failure models and failure criteria. Yet, developers and users of software and computer tools are normally faced with a difficult problem deciding which failure model should be selected or used in a particular application. Consequently, the situation requires a conscious ‘operator intervention’ to make that selection, based on an examination of the problem to be analysed but otherwise with very little further guidance available currently to help make an informed decision. From a designer’s perspective, the preference would be the provision of modelling tools with assured resilience that predictions would be accurate in all circumstances.

As a result of the first World Wide Failure Exercise1, crucial gaps were identified. The authors of the first exercise (Hinton and Kaddour) organised a new activity, called the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-II) to bridge some of those gaps.2 In Kaddour and Hinton,2 the organisers described the background to the WWFE-II, highlighted the challenging issues facing the composite community and set out a plan for carrying out all stages of the exercise. The strategy used in the first exercise was adopted for the second exercise as it was proven to be robust and mature and able to handle with a wide range of challenges and eventualities.

The WWFE-II was set up to assess the maturity of failure criteria for predicting the strength and deformation of materials under three-dimensional (3D) stresses (triaxial loadings). It runs into two parts, referred to as Part (A) and Part (B), where Part (A) deals with comparison between blind predictions of various theories and Part (B) deals with comparing the blind predictions with experimental results.

In Part A, 12 leading theories were employed by their originators (or their representatives) to solve 12 problems (test cases). The test cases are described in detail in Kaddour and Hinton3 and the results of the individual theoretical predictions are described in various other references.4–15

This article presents a comprehensive comparison of the predictive capabilities of the 12 failure theories,4–15 for analysing failure and deformation of all of the 12 test cases under 3D stresses (i.e. triaxial loadings).

sec.title: Description of the failure theories employed in WWFE-II
Introduction
sec.p:
Prior to describing the theories it is worth providing a brief outline of the selection of the test cases analysed by the participants. The WWFE-II was set up to assess how the current failure models can predict failure under 3D stresses. For this reason, the originators of failure theories were provided with 12 test cases, selected and provided by the organisers. These test cases are listed in Table 1 and they include tests on an unreinforced matrix, a unidirectional laminate and multi-directional laminates both unidirectional (UD) lamina and multi-directional laminates. They include five lay-ups: an isotropic polymer material, UD laminae, cross-ply laminate, angle-ply laminate and quasi-isotropic laminate. Six different fibre/matrix combinations were used and these are: an epoxy, T300/epoxy, E-glass/epoxy, S-glass/epoxy, AS Carbon/epoxy and IM7/8551 materials. Table 1.
Details of the laminates and loading (test) cases

The coordinate system used to describe the stresses in a lamina is shown in Figure 1(a), where directions 1, 2 and 3 coincide with fibre direction, transverse direction and through-thickness direction, respectively. In the present analysis, the application of equal triaxial compressive stresses is commonly referred to as hydrostatic compressive loading where: (σ1) = (σ2) = (σ3) = −P where P is the equivalent hydrostatic pressure. Similarly, the application of equal triaxial tension (i.e. (+σ1) = (+σ2) = (+σ3)) causes an analogous hydrostatic tensile state (i.e. +P). Figure 1.
(a) A schematic of a composite lamina under triaxial states of stress. Directions 1, 2 and 3 coincide with fibre, transverse and through-thickness directions. (b) A schematic showing selected stress ratios in the eight octants.

sec.title: Identification of the theories
sec.p:
The contributors to WWFE-II were selected to represent a variety of the most important current approaches dealing with 3D stress analysis. Table 2 provides a list of the names of the participants and indicates the 12 approaches they employed. Table 2.
A summary of participants and approaches represented in WWFE-II
I.D.no. Participants’ names Organisation Approach represented Theory designation
1 Bogetti, Staniszewski, Burns, Hoppel, Gillespie and Tierney13 U.S. Army Research Laboratory (USA) 3D Maximum strain theory Bogettia
2 Carrere, Laurin and Maire10 ONERA/DMSC (France) Micromechanical-based hybrid mesoscopic (MHM) 3D approach Carrere
3 Cuntze4 Retired Engineer (Germany) Failure mode concept (FMC) model Cuntzea
4 Huang, Jin, Ha and Tsai15 Hanyang University (S Korea), Stanford University (USA) Micromechanics of failure (MMF) model Tsai–Haa
5 Nelson, Hansen and Mayes6 Firehole Technologies, Wyoming University, Alfred University (USA) Mult-continuum micromechanics (MCT) theory Hansena
6 Zhou and Huang12 Tongji University (China) Anisotropic plasticity and generalised max stress Huanga
7 Kress5 ETZ Zurich (Switzerland) Hashin’s model Hashin
8 Pinho, Darvizeh, Robinson, Schuecker and Camanho9 Imperial College (UK), University of Porto (Portugal) 3D physically-based constitutive model Pinho
9 Deuschle and Kröplin7 ISD, Stuttgart university (Germany) Physically based 3D phenomenological model Pucka
10 Rotem14 Technion University (Israel) Interactive matrix and fibre failure theory Rotema
11 Zand, Wolfe, Butalia and Schoeppner11 Ohio State University, AFRL, Wright-Patterson, AFB, Ohio (USA) Maximum strain energy method Wolfea
12 Ye and Zhang8 Leeds University, Manchester University (UK) Christensen’s theory Christensen
a
These theories were used in the first WWFE.

For the sake of simple identification and quick referencing, each of the theories is referred to by a single name (see the last column in Table 2). For those papers that are single-authored, the name of the theory is that of the author himself. These include Cuntze,4 and Rotem.14 However, for those papers that are co-authored, the name of one key author is given, although this key author may not be the sole originator of the theory. These include the following:
(a) Bogetti, Staniszewski, Burns, Hoppel, Gillespie and Tierney13 Bogetti
(b) Carrere, Laurin and Maire10 Carrere
(c) Huang, Jin, Ha and Tsai15 Tsai–Ha
(d) Nelson, Hansen and Mayes6 Hansen
(e) Zhou and Huang12 Huang
(f) Pinho, Darvizeh, Robinson, Schuecker and Camanho9 Pinho
(g) Zand, Wolfe, Butalia and Schoeppner11 Wolfe

The WWFE-II contains three submissions where the authors (participants) are not the originators of the models (theories) employed but they were requested to cover and represent models that were originated and developed by others. In this case, the name of originator of the failure theory was used rather than a key author. These groups are:
(a) Kress,5 who represented Hashin’s failure criteria Hashin
(b) Ye and Zhang,8 who represented Christensen’s theory Christensen
(c) Deuschle and Kröplin,7 who represented Puck’s theory Puck

sec.title: Characteristics of the theories
sec.p:
Each of the theories is thought to be best characterised by a number of key features which are categorised in Table 3 as follows: Table 3.

5 Hansen 3DLT + FE Nonlinear No Yes Yes Yes FE-based (ABAQUS)

sec.title: Method of analysis
sec.p: Column 3 of Table 3 indicates whether a three-dimensional laminate theory (3DLT) alone or combined with a finite element (FE) program was used in carrying out the predictions. All of the contributors utilised 3DLT as the main ‘calculation engine’ on which to base their theory. A number of the participants utilised finite element methods (Pinho, Tsai–Ha, Puck and Hansen).

sec.title: Type of analysis (Table 3, Column 4)
sec.p: This refers to whether linear or nonlinear material properties were considered. All of the participants used nonlinear analysis, except Christensen, who employed linear analysis in the implementation of his theory.

sec.title: Thermal stresses (Table 3, Column 5)
sec.p: All of the participants were aware of the presence of the thermal stresses. However, a significant portion of the participants (Christensen, Pinho, Wolfe, Bogetti, Cuntze and Hashin) did not take residual thermal stresses into account in some or all in Test Cases. Other contributors did consider the thermal stresses, but not all in the same way or to the same extent. For example, Huang was the only contributor to provide an analysis that considers residual stresses at the micromechanics (i.e. resin and fibres) level.

sec.title: Modes of failure (Table 3, Column 6)
sec.p: All of the theories were able to discriminate between a minimum of two modes of failure and, in general, a wide variety of modes was postulated including:- fibre failure (tension, compression or shear) to matrix failure (due to transverse tension, transverse compression, shear or a combination of these three). In most cases the theories used the lamina properties (provided to all participants) from which to predict the modes of failure rather than constituent (fibre or matrix) properties. However, Hansen, Huang and Tsai–Ha used the constituent fibre and matrix properties (also provided to all participants) for determining failure.

sec.title: Micromechanics (Table 3, Column 7)
sec.p:
The majority of models consider the failure behaviour of the matrix to be different to that of the UD lamina. However, some of the methods (Huang, Carrere, Tsai–Ha, Hansen) rely on suitable micromechanics relationships to predict the behaviour of the lamina and the laminates from that of the matrix and the reinforcing fibres.
Huang’s theory relies on micro mechanics for determining the UD lamina properties. Huang used the nonlinear shear stress/strain curves of the matrix to determine the nonlinear behaviour of the lamina. Using a ‘bridging’ model, he adjusted the constituent properties to give lamina properties close to those provided in the exercise.
Hansen’s and Tsai–Ha’s theories are micromechanics based. Finite element analyses were employed to predict lamina properties from constituent properties, assuming linear elastic fibres and non-linear elastic matrix behaviour and allowing one constituent to fail while the other remains intact. Tsai–Ha also adjusted the constituent properties to give lamina properties close to those provided in the exercise.
Others (Cuntze, Rotem, Pinho) have used micromechanics to obtain modified elastic constants, and occasionally strength data, of a lamina under hydrostatic pressure.

sec.title: Post-initial failure degradation models (Table 3, Column 8)
sec.p:
This entry specifies whether or not the theory used any degradation model to account for post initial failure behaviour. Multidirectional laminates subjected to uniaxial, biaxial or triaxial stresses may still be capable of carrying load after first ply failure or initial failure has occurred. Modelling post failure behaviour of a laminate requires that certain assumptions be made regarding the properties of the degraded lamina. All of these models shared the following common features:
All rely on ply-by-ply analysis.
All assume that fibre failure, be it in tension or in compression, constitutes final failure. In certain instances, and in order to take into account hydrostatic pressure effects, the models introduced a pressure dependency term to the fibre compression failure strength, making the lamina too strong to fail.
Almost all models distinguish between failures under transverse tension and that under transverse compression. Here the term ‘transverse’ is used to refer to the direction perpendicular to the fibres, i.e. direction 2 in Figure 1, in a UD fibre-reinforced lamina.
The majority of the models were unable to take into account any differences in the strengths of the lamina in the through-thickness and in the transverse directions (ie the models were based on assumption of transverse isotropy).

sec.title: Title of computer program used (Table 3, Column 9)
sec.p: In view of the complexity of many of the theories, most of the participants have developed their own computer code and the entry in the last column of Table 3 lists the name of the computer program used by the participants. For the test cases corresponding to UD plies (test cases 1–7), some of the participants obtained their predictions using a simple explicit code (Fortran, MATLAB, MathCad, etc.) that solves the lamina constitutive relations together with the appropriate failure criteria used. For the multi-directional laminates (test cases 8–12), and owing to the fact that the loadings involves 3D stresses, some participants employed 3D explicit finite element code to calculate the 3D ply stresses, as these were seen to impossible to obtain from classical lamination theory.

In summary, the participants have either coupled their analysis into a commercial code (Tsai–Ha, Hansen, Puck and Pinho), or written their own (Bogetti, Hashin, Rotem, Huang, Cuntze, Wolfe, Carrere and Christensen). These latter codes were written in various languages (Visual Basic, Fortran, Matlab, MathCad, etc.).

sec.title: Breadth of cases analysed by each participant
sec.p: The participants were set 12 test cases for analysis and these are summarised in Table 1. The composite systems, laminate configurations and load combinations for the test cases have been described in detail in Kaddour and Hinton.3

Table 4 shows the test cases attempted by each contributor. The majority of the participants were able to analyse all of the cases. However, there were some notable shortfalls:
Cuntze did not provide a solution for test case 10.
Christensen did not provide solutions for test cases 10 and 11.
Bogetti provided an incorrect solution for test case 12, as he provided the behaviour under tension rather than that under compression. This problem was later rectified in his Part B submission (awaiting publication).

sec.title: Modifications made to theories used in the WWFE-I
sec.p: Eight of the 12 theories were employed and assessed in WWFE-I and these are marked in Table 2. However it is worth noting that originators of some of these theories have had to make modifications in order to extend what were essentially 2-D formulation's that (arguably) sufficed for WWFE-I into a 3-D formulation that could be employed in WWFE-II. In those instances, it leaves an open question as to whether the reformulated 3-D variants would give the same or different predictions to those made by the 2-D variant against the original WWFE-I test cases. In at least one instance (Huang) the contributor has carried out that comparison (paper in draft and awaiting publication) and we encourage the other contributors to do likewise in due course.
A summary of the key changes that were made in the eight ‘original WWFE-1' theories is as follows :-

sec.title: Bogetti’s theory
sec.p: No modification was made in this theory.

sec.title: Hansen’s theory
sec.p:
Four modifications were introduced and these are listed as:
A new quadratic matrix failure criterion.
A coupling added between shear and transverse compression stresses.
Post-failure degradation model was developed to account for a more gradual reduction in failed matrix material properties.
Incorporation of hydrostatic pressure effects on materials response.

sec.title: Cuntze’s theory
sec.p:
Four modifications were made and these are listed as
Failure criterion of polymer materials.
Modification to IFF3, which is one of the five failure conditions.
Introduction of pressure effects on elastic constants.
Introduction of second glass temperature effects on strength values.

sec.title: Tsai–Ha’s theory
sec.p:
The theory presented in this exercise was radically different to that employed in WWFE-I. The new modifications include the following:
Elimination of the interactive Tsai–Wu quadratic equation.
Introduction of 3D microscopic unit cell.
Introduction of fibre failure criterion.
Introduction of matrix failure criterion.
Introduction of interface failure criterion.
Implementation of finite element.
Inclusion of nonlinear analysis.
Matrix damage progression.

sec.title: Rotem’s theory
sec.p:
Rotem introduced the following modifications:
Failure criterion for isotropic materials.
A new fibre failure criterion, accounting for the transversely isotropic stress.
A new transversely isotropic failure criterion.
A new deviatory and shear failure criterion.
Accounting for post failure in the through-thickness direction.

sec.title: Wolfe’s theory
sec.p:
The modifications included the following features
Failure criterion for isotropic materials.
Elimination of stain energy conservation principle for the nonlinear analysis.
‘Robust’ post failure analysis.
Introduction of failure mode concept.
Introduction of a parameter for taking hydrostatic pressure effects on fibre failure.

sec.title: Huang’s theory
sec.p:
The following modifications were employed by Huang:
A pseudo 3DLT incorporated with the 3D bridging model formulae was used.
A partial stiffness discount scheme is applied to the failed lamina, in which the modulus of resin material is replaced by 1% of its original magnitude.
In order to account for the effect of a 3D compression on increasing the load-carrying ability of a resin material, a modified maximum compressive stress failure criterion was introduced to detect its compressive failure.
Introduction of the resin-rich interfacial layer between adjacent plies.

sec.title: Puck’s theory
sec.p:
The following were introduced to the model:
Modification of theory for isotropic behaviour.
Introduction of self-similar relationship for extending nonlinear curves.
Employment of finite element method for 3D stress analysis.
Considerations of geometrical nonlinearity.
In situ enhancement for some of the UD strengths (only in-plane transverse strength and the in-plane transverse/longitudinal shear strength).

It can be concluded that the majority of the eight theories that were employed in WWFE-I received significant revision to cater for failure prediction under 3D stress states. The largest modifications have taken place in the Tsai–Ha theory. The new theory, referred to as micromechanics of failure (MMF) is fundamentally different to that originally developed by Tsai.1

sec.title: Comparison between various theories
sec.p:
In order to facilitate the task of comparing the predictions from the 12 theories for the 12 test cases, the following approach was taken:
Graphs were produced containing the superimposed predictions of all the various theories for each test case.
In addition, bar charts of strengths (and, where appropriate, strains) predicted by all of the theories were constructed at specific conditions of loading within the 12 test cases.
The largest differences between the predictions of all the theories for some of the loading combinations are recorded in suitable tables (Tables 5 to 7).
Attention is drawn to areas and loading conditions where the theories predicted open envelopes and large deformations.

Table 5 shows a list of the same theories and indicates whether these theories predicted an initial and final failure in the test cases. The table shows the following features:
For some of the theories, the prediction of intial and final failures depended upon the test cases.
Tsai–Ha predicted initial and final envelopes for all of the test cases.
Bogetti, Cuntze, Hashin, Pinho, Puck and Christensen, predicted one envelope only for all of the test cases.
Carrere, Huang, Rotem and Wolfe predicted initial and final envelopes only for test cases 8–12.

Further details are provided in the following sections where a comparison is made between the predictions of all the theories for each of the test cases, separately. It should be noted here that, as WWFE-II deals with 3D stress analysis, the Euclidean coordinate system will, ideally, have eight octants (Figure 1(b)). Hence, in some situations, the state of the stresses will be described according to the octant they belong to.

sec.title: Test case 1: Behaviour of an epoxy under triaxial loading
sec.p:
A comparison between the predictions of the various theories is shown in Figure 2. The following remarks can be made:
With the exception of Pinho and Christensen, each theory predicted a unique envelope that was different to that predicted by the rest of the theories. The predictions from Pinho and Christensen models were identical where both used the same equations to describe the failure of an isotropic material.
One model (Hansen’s) predicted an open envelope in both the tension and the compression octant.
With the exception of two models (Hashin and Bogetti who predicted closed envelopes in the tension–tension–tension and the compression–compression–compression octants), all the 10 remaining theories predicted open envelopes in the compression–compression–compression octant.
Figure 2.
Superimposed theoretical failure envelopes predicted by the participants of WWFE-II for test case 1. Failure of MY750 epoxy material under triaxial stresses. Top graph: Full envelopes. Bottom graph is an enlarged picture of the upper-right quadrant of the top graph.
Depending upon the stress ratio applied, the behaviour under tension was different to that under compression as described below:

list-item.p: One theory (Hansen’s) predicted an open envelope under tension–tension–tension loading.
Five theories (Hashin, Bogetti, Rotem, Cuntze and Carrere) predicted various forms of cut-off in this area.

Four of the theories (Ha, Carrere, Huang and Hashin) predicted no enhancement in the strength and the rest did. The largest enhancement, apart from that related to the open envelope in Hansen’s theory, was observed in Bogetti’s theory with the equi-triaxial tensile strength (267.3 MPa) being 3.3 that of the uniaxial tensile strength (81 MPa).

It was noted that some of the participants introduced various forms of cut-offs in the envelopes in the tension–tension space. These were introduced to indicate the dominance of different modes of failure.
The ratio of the highest strength, predicted by Bogetti, to the lowest strength, predicted by Carrere, was 6.95.

sec.title: In the compression–compression–compression octant

list-item.p: Two of the theories (Hashin and Bogetti) predicted closed envelope under compression–compression–compression loadings. One of them (Hashin) predicted no enhancement in the strength and hence provided the most conservative prediction in this octant.

All other 10 theories predicted open envelopes. However, the shapes of these envelopes were different to each other and thus, for any given stress ratio, the failure stresses are different for different theories. For instance, at an arbitrary stress ratio of σx: σy: σz = −0.439: −1: −1, the largest stress is predicted by Cuntze and the ratio between Cuntze’s prediction and Hashin’s prediction is 8.33 (Table 7). This ratio increases as the stress ratio moves toward the hydrostatic pressure line.

sec.p: It was noted that the theory presented by Tsai–Ha predicted an initial and a final failure envelope. Also, the theory presented by Huang gave two envelopes: one with thermal stresses and one without thermal stresses with no directive provided as to which of the two should be preferred.

sec.title: Test case 2: Strength failure envelope for carbon/epoxy lamina under combined pressure and shear loading
sec.p:
Figure 3 shows various graphs comparing the predicted results obtained from the various theories. A number of observations may be made:
No enhancement in the shear was predicted under tension stresses.
With the exception of one theory (Bogetti), the 11 theories predicted an enhancement in shear strength under compressive loadings. Each of the 12 theories produced a unique shape of failure envelopes. However, the location of the maximum shear strength varied from one method to another. Christensen predicted the maximum shear strength at −31.7 MPa pressure whereas Cuntze predicted the same at −1750 MPa, Hashin at −950 MPa and Puck at −1003 MPa pressure.
The bar charts shown in Figure 4 show that
The largest shear strength was reported by Hashin. The ratio of the highest shear strength from Hashin to the lowest strength (from Huang) is 4.
Some theories predicted open envelopes under compression. For those theories predicting closed envelopes, the ratio of the highest predicted hydrostatic pressure (from Cuntze’s theory) to the lowest predicted hydrostatic pressure (from Christensen’s theory) is 19.5.
For hydrostatic tension, with no shear stress, the ratio between the highest (Tsai–Ha’s theory) and lowest (Hansen’s theory) predicted strength is 3.1.
Figure 3.
Superimposed theoretical failure envelopes predicted by the participants of WWFE-II for test case 2. Ultimate shear strength of carbon/epoxy lamina under combined hydrostatic pressure and shear loading. Top graph: Full envelopes. Bottom graph is blown up picture of the right hand side of the top graph. Figure 4.
Bar charts showing the theoretical predictions of the participants of WWFE-II for test case 2. Top: hydrostatic compressive strength. Middle: ratio of maximum shear strength/UD shear strength. Bottom: Maximum shear strength under hydrostatic compression.

For some of those theories that employed micromechanics (Ha and Huang), the predicted uniaxial shear strength (with no pressure), was much lower than that provided by the organisers. As a consequence, and partly due to the predicted uniaxial shear strength, the maximum shear strength, under combined loadings, was lower than those predicted by others.

sec.title: Test case 3: Ultimate failure shear strain envelope for carbon/epoxy lamina under combined pressure and shear loading
sec.p:
This case is similar to that described above, except that the ultimate shear strain is plotted as a function of equal triaxial stress. As far as the failure shear strain is concerned, the following observations can be made from the plotted envelopes (Figure 5), and the bar charts (Figure 6).
With the exception of Rotem and Bogetti, all of the theories that predicted an enhancement (under compression) and a reduction (under tension) in the strength, did the same in the failure strain. Although Rotem predicted an enhancement in strength he assumed that the strain is unaffected by the pressure.
The largest increase in the shear strain was observed in Hashin’ theory where the maximum shear strain was 3.8 of that under pure shear loading.
It should be noted here that, for those theories predicting open envelopes (Hansen, Carrere and Pinho), no data is presented regarding the ratio between the maximum shear strain under combined loading and that under uniaxial loading (pure shear).
Figure 5.
Superimposed theoretical failure envelopes predicted by the participants of WWFE-II for test case 3. Failure shear strain for carbon/epoxy lamina under combined hydrostatic pressure and shear loading. Top graph: Full envelopes. Bottom graph is blown up picture of the right hand side of the top graph. Figure 6.
Bar charts showing the theoretical predictions of the participants of WWFE-II for test case 3. Maximum shear strain of UD lamina under superimposed hydrostatic pressure.

As shown above, the majority of the theories predicted an enhancement in failure strain in the presence of hydrostatic pressure. In this situation, the participants employed various mechanisms for predicting the influence of pressure on shear failure strain.
Christensen computed the failure shear strain from the predicted shear strength and the elastic shear modulus of the material. Christensen’s method employed linear stress analysis and hence the nonlinearity in the shear stress–strain curves was not taken into account.
Puck and Wolfe employed ‘self-similar approach’ to compute the failure shear strain from the predicted shear strength. This approach assumes that shear stress–strain curve is similar at all the pressure values and that the secant shear modulus, computed at maximum shear stress, is the same at all pressure values.
Hashin extended the shear stress–strain curves linearly beyond the values provided by the organisers for the UD lamina.
Hansen extended the shear stress–strain curves nonlinearly beyond those values provided by the organisers for the UD lamina.

sec.title: Test case 4: Shear stress-strain curve under −600 MPa pressure for carbon/epoxy lamina under combined pressure and shear loading
sec.p:
Figure 7 shows a comparison between the predicted shear stress–strain curves under −600 MPa hydrostatic pressure. The bar charts in Figure 8 show values for the strength and ultimate failure strain, predicted by all the participants. The following observations are made regarding the differences and similarities between the results:
With the exception of Christensen, who used linear analysis, all participants used nonlinear analysis.
Both Christensen and Bogetti predicted the lamina to fail at pressure values much less than the 600 MPa provided by the organisers. In reality, these two models must not have produced any stress–strain curves as the material has already failed at relatively low pressure.
Rotem and Bogetti predicted the same failure strain as that of a lamina without pressure.
Huang predicted a failure strain of 2.97% that was less than that of a lamina without pressure and was the lowest predicted strain.
Hashin extended the curve linearly above the data provided by the organisers. The predicted final strain was the largest among the strains predicted by other models and that was 9 times higher than that of Huang’s model.
The shear strength predicted by Hashin was the highest (305.5 MPa). This was a factor of 6.2 higher than that predicted by Huang.
In terms of the effect of pressure on the shape of the shear stress-strain curves, there was a lack of consensus on how to predict the curves and hence the models were split into two categories: (a) Models predicting no effects up to the UD data provided by the organisers. These include Christensen, Hashin, Bogetti and Hansen.
– Bogetti and Christensen terminated the curves at the same stress as that observed under no pressure (i.e. atmospheric pressure).
– Hashin extended the curve linearly, keeping the same secant modulus, whereas Hansen extended his curve nonlinearly. (b) Models predicting some effects up to, and beyond, the UD data provided by the organisers. These include the rest of the models (Rotem, Puck, Wolfe, Cuntze, Carrere, Pinho, Huang and Tsai–Ha).
– Puck and Wolfe used the ‘self-similar approach’ to predict the shape of the shear stress–strain curve under −600 MPa.
– Pinho, Rotem, Cuntze and Carrere assumed some forms of pressure dependency on the shear modulus and shear strength at elevated pressures.
Figure 7.
Superimposed theoretical stress–strain curves predicted by the participants of WWFE-II for test case 4. Shear stress–strain curves for carbon/epoxy lamina under hydrostatic pressure. Top graph: Prediction from six participants. Bottom: Predictions from the other six participants. Figure 8.
Bar charts showing the theoretical predictions of the participants of WWFE-II for test case 4. Top: ultimate shear failure strains, taken from Figure 7. Bottom: corresponding ultimate shear strength.

sec.title: Test case 5: Strength envelopes for E-glass/MY750 lamina under combined direct stresses
sec.p:
This test case is concerned with the prediction of the strength envelope of a UD lamina under combined σ2, σ3 and σ1 where σ3 = σ1. The theoretical results are shown in Figures 9 and 10. A number of interesting features were observed in the predictions:
Compression–compression–compression (−σ1, −σ2, −σ3) octant:
The behaviour of the lamina under compressive–compressive–compressive loading was reported by some participants to be very strong, with no failure. Three models (Pinho, Carrere and Hansen) predicted an open envelope. The strength (σ2) predicted made by Cuntze was also relatively high where, at the stress ratio −σ2: −σ1: −σ3 = −1.42:−1:−1, the strength σ2 reached −3563 MPa, almost 25 times the uniaxial transverse compressive strength of the lamina.
For those closed envelopes, the ratio between the highest prediction (−1818 MPa, by Cuntze) and the lowest prediction (−147.4 MPa, by Christensen) is 12.3 under −σ2 = −σ1 = −σ3. Four of the theories (Hashin, Puck, Rotem and Wolfe) predicted the strength under −σ2 = −σ1 = −σ3 to be close to the UD longitudinal compressive strength (−800 MPa).
Tension–tension–tension octant:
Three of the models (Bogetti, Tsai–Ha and Rotem) predicted an enhancement in the strength (σ2) whereas the rest showed either no effects (Pinho and Carrere) or a reduction in the strength below the uniaxial UD strength. The maximum enhancement reported by Bogetti is 66% in relation to the UD strength value (40 MPa) that was provided by the organisers.
For +σ2 = +σ1 = +σ3 loading, the ratio of the highest (Bogetti) to the lowest (Hansen) triaxial tensile strength prediction was 3.16
Huang predicted a high uniaxial strength value in relation to the value provided by the organisers.
Figure 9.
Superimposed theoretical failure envelopes predicted by the participants of WWFE-II for test case 5. Failure strength envelopes for E-glass/epoxy lamina under triaxial stresses. Top graph: Full envelopes. Middle graph is an enlarged picture of the upper two quadrants (tensile σ2 stress) of the top graph. Bottom: Enlargement of the lower-right quadrant (envelopes under: −σ2, +σ3, + σ1). Figure 10.
Bar charts showing the theoretical predictions of the participants of WWFE-II for test case 5. Compressive hydrostatic pressure values are taken from Figure 9.

sec.title: Test case 6: Strength failure envelopes for glass/epoxy lamina under combined direct stresses
sec.p:
This test case is concerned with the prediction of the strength envelope of a UD glass/epoxy lamina under combined σ1, σ2 and σ3 where σ2 = σ3. The theoretical results are shown in Figures 11 and 12. A number of interesting features were observed in the predictions: Figure 11.
Superimposed theoretical failure envelopes predicted by the participants of WWFE-II for test case 6. Failure of S-glass/epoxy lamina under triaxial stresses. Top graph: Full envelopes. Bottom graph is an enlargement of the upper two quadrants (positive σ2 stress) of the top graph. Figure 12.
Bar charts showing the theoretical predictions of the participants of WWFE-II for test case 6. Top: Biaxial compressive strength, Middle: Biaxial tensile strength. Bottom: hydrostatic compressive strength.

list-item.p: In general, all of the theories predicted that the UD lamina would exhibit very high failure strengths in this octant. In all the theories employed, the strength σ1 either remained constant or increased due to the presence of the compressive stresses σ2 = σ3. Seven models (Pinho, Carrere, Hansen, Hashin, Cuntze, Puck and Wolfe) predicted open envelopes and the remaining five (Bogetti, Christensen, Tsai–Ha, Huang, and Rotem) predicted closed envelopes. Pinho, Carrere and Hansen theories predicted higher rate of increase in σ1 with σ2 than those of Cuntze, Wolfe, Puck and Hashin. The latter showed a failure at a constant longitudinal compressive stress (corresponding to the UD strength of −1150 MPa).

Although some of the theories (Puck, Cuntze, Hashin) predicted envelopes that were open, they produced failure under hydrostatic pressure (−σ2 = −σ3 = −σ1) (Figure 12). The ratio of highest to lowest strength prediction was 5.14. The graph shows that a value was assigned to Puck’s theory and this was based on a linear extrapolation of the curves plotted in Puck’s paper.

The theories gave a large variation in the prediction of the biaxial failure stress −σ2 = −σ3 (taken at σ1 = 0) (Figure 12). The largest of the highest strength (Cuntze’s theory) to the lowest strength (Bogetti’s model) was 9.16.

sec.title: Tension–tension–tension (+σ1, +σ2, +σ3) octant. The theories could be grouped as follows

list-item.p: Group showing an enhancement in the strengths values: Only one model (Bogetti’s) predicted an enhancement in the longitudinal tensile strength (σ1), due to the application of tensile stresses σ2 = σ3.
Group showing a form of interaction: These consist of six models (Huang, Hansen, Puck, Cuntze, Carrere and Tsai–Ha).
Group showing no interaction: These consist of five models (Rotem, Pinho, Wolfe, Hashin and Christensen). Their predictions produced somewhat rectangular envelope.

sec.title: Test case 7: Strength failure envelopes for carbon/epoxy lamina under combined direct stresses
sec.p:
This test case is similar to that described above and is concerned with the prediction of the strength envelope of a UD carbon/epoxy lamina under combined σ1, σ2 and σ3 where σ2 = σ3. The theoretical results are shown in Figures 13 and 14. A number of interesting features were observed in the predictions: Figure 13.
Superimposed theoretical failure envelopes predicted by the participants of WWFE-II for test case 7. Failure of carbon/epoxy lamina under triaxial stresses. Top graph: Full envelopes. Bottom graph is an enlarged picture of the upper two quadrants (positive σ2 stress) of the top graph. Figure 14.
Bar charts showing the theoretical predictions of the participants of WWFE-II for test case 6. Top: Biaxial compressive strength. Bottom: hydrostatic compressive strength.

list-item.p: The behaviour of the lamina under compressive–compressive–compressive loading was reported by some participants to be very strong or even with no failure. In all the theories employed, the compressive strength −σ1 either remained constant or increased due to the application of compressive stresses −σ2 = −σ3. Seven models (Pinho, Carrere, Hansen, Hashin, Cuntze, Puck and Wolfe) predicted open envelopes and the remaining five (Bogetti, Christensen, Tsai–Ha, Huang and Rotem) predicted closed envelopes. Carrere and Hansen theories predicted higher rate of increase in σ1 with σ2 than that of Cuntze, Wolfe, Puck, Pinho and Hashin. The latter showed a failure at a constant longitudinal compressive stress (equal to the UD strength).

Although some of the theories (Puck, Cuntze and Hashin) predicted envelopes that were open, they produced failure under hydrostatic pressure (−σ2 = −σ3 = −σ1) (Figure 13 and 14). The ratio of highest strength, predicted by Cuntze, to lowest strength, predicted by Christensen, was 10. This is much larger than that seen in test case 6.

The theories gave a large variation in the prediction of the biaxial failure stress −σ2 = −σ3 (taken at σ1 = 0) (Figure 14). The largest ratio between the highest strength (Cuntze’s theory) and the lowest strength (Christensen’s model) was 13.4. This is larger than that seen in test case 6.

sec.title: Tension–tension–tension (+σ1, +σ2, +σ3) octant. The theories could be grouped as follows

list-item.p: Group showing an enhancement in the strengths values:Only one model (Bogetti’s) predicted an enhancement in the longitudinal tensile strength (σ1), due to the application of tensile stresses σ2 = σ3. At a stress ratio σ1: σ2 (=: σ3) = 12.86:1, the difference between the predictions was at a maximum where the ratio of largest strength (162 MPa, predicted by Bogetti) to lowest strength (19.9 MPa, predicted by Hansen) was 8.14. This ratio is much higher than that corresponding to σ1 = 0 where Bogetti’s theory predicted a strength that was 3.76 higher than that of Hansen’s theory.
Group showing a form of a nonlinear interaction: These consist of six models (Huang, Hansen, Puck, Cuntze, Carrere and Tsai–Ha).
Group showing no interaction: These consist of five models (Rotem, Pinho, Wolfe, Hashin and Christensen). Their predictions produced somewhat rectangular envelope.

sec.p:
The shapes of the envelopes of test case 7 are generally similar to those of test case 6, with the following exceptions:
Pinho’s curve under −σ1, −σ2, −σ3 loading for case 7 was much shallower than that for case 6.
Huang’s curve under −σ1, −σ2, −σ3 loading for case 7 did not have the same cut-off predicted in case 6.

sec.title: Test case 8: Failure envelope for (±35°)s E-glass/MY750 epoxy laminate under combined σy, σz and σx
sec.p:
It is well known that the ±35° (using the axis nomenclature of WWFE-II) angle-ply laminate is commonly employed in pipes and pressure vessels and the behaviour of this laminate under biaxial in-plane stresses (σy and σx) was studied extensively in the first exercise.1 In the previous exercise, the laminate was referred to as ±55° angle-ply laminate (noting that this is the complementary angle for ±35°). Here, the behaviour of the same laminate is studied under 3D stresses, including through-thickness direct stresses. The final failure envelopes and the stresses predicted by the participants are shown in Figures 15 and 16. Bar charts are also presented comparing the failure stresses at selected triaxial stress ratios. Figure 15.
Superimposed theoretical failure envelopes predicted by the participants of WWFE-II for test case 8. Failure of ±35° Glass/epoxy laminates under triaxial stresses. Top graph: Full envelopes. Bottom graph is an enlarged picture of the upper two quadrants (positive σy stress) of the top graph. Figure 16.
Bar charts showing the theoretical predictions of the participants of WWFE-II for test case 8. Top: Biaxial compressive strength, Middle: Tensile strength. Bottom: hydrostatic compressive strength.
A number of features may be observed from the superimposed curves. They could be classified as follows:

sec.title: Initial and final failure envelopes
sec.p: Six of the models (Rotem, Carrere, Tsai–Ha, Wolfe, Hansen and Huang) predicted initial failure envelopes that were different to the final failure envelopes. The initial failure envelopes are not shown in the present article and readers can find all of the details in the individual papers and in Part B of the WWFE-II. The other six provided one envelope describing the final (initial) failure stresses.

sec.title: Prediction of open and closed envelopes
sec.p: Four of the models (Hansen, Pinho, Carrere and Wolfe) seem to indicate that the envelope is open under triaxial compression. The rest of the models gave predictions with closed envelopes.

sec.title: Behaviour in compression–compression–compression octant
sec.p: All the theories predicted an increase in the laminate strength under triaxial compression (i.e. under combined −x, −σy, −σz loadings. The degree of enhancement varied from one theory to another with Cuntze predicting the largest enhancement and Christensen predicting the lowest. In addition the loading ratio at which the maximum strength took place varied from one theory to another. Tsai–Ha’s theory predicted a peak stress at −σx: −σz: −σy = −404.8:−404.8:−233.7 (i.e. at −σx: −σy = −1.73:−1) and Hashin’s theory at −712:−721:−1096.5 (i.e. at σx: −σy = −0.65:-1)

The theories also showed a large variation in the strength of the laminate under hydrostatic pressure (equitriaxial strength where −σx = −σz = −σy). As the bar chart in Figure 16 shows, the strength varies from −145 MPa, predicted by Christensen, to −1582 MPa, predicted by Cuntze with the ratio between them reaching 11.

sec.title: Behaviour under tensile stress in y-direction
sec.p:
Figures 15 and 16 shows the various envelopes predicted under tensile loading in the y-direction. A number of observations may me made:
No two theories predicted the same shape of envelopes.
Six models predicted an enhancement in the strength under triaxial tension (i.e. under tensile σx stresses) while the other five or six predicted an enhancement under compressive −σx loading. In each of these octants, the location and the magnitude of peak stress varies from one model to another.
Even under uniaxial tensile stress applied in y-direction (σz = σx = 0), the theories gave a large range of predictions varying from 40 MPa, predicted by Cuntze, to 124 MPa, predicted by Hansen, with the ratio between them being 3.1.
For a loading ratio σz: σx: σy = 2: 2: 1, the theories produced a range of predictions varying from 12 MPa (Christensen’s prediction) to 49 MPa (Huang’s prediction) giving a ratio of 4.125 between these two extreme predictions.
For σy = 0, the biaxial tensile strength (σz = σx) ranged from 28 MPa (Christensen’s model) to 102.3 MPa (Huang’s model) giving a ratio of 3.65 between these two extreme predictions. Similarly, large differences were predicted for the biaxial compressive strength (−σz = −σx) where the values ranged from −90 MPa (Tsai–Ha’s model) to −314 MPa (Hansen’s model) giving a ratio of 3.48 between these two extreme predictions.

sec.title: Test case 9: Stress–strain curves for (±35°)s E-glass/MY750 epoxy laminate under combined σy, σz and σx
sec.p:
In this case, the laminate was first subjected to a hydrostatic pressure of σy = σz = σx = −100 MPa and then the stresses σz = σx was kept constant while the stress σy was increased up to final failure. The stress–strain curves are shown in Figure 17 and the bar charts in Figure 18 show a comparison between the final failure stresses and strains obtained from the 12 models. The following observations may be made.
All the models, except that of Cuntze, show almost identical behaviour during the hydrostatic pressure loading. Cuntze's model is later corrected in Part B of the WWFE-II.
All the models, except that of Christensen involved nonlinear predictions.
The shapes of the stress–strain curves were similar in almost all of the predictions. However, Hansen and Pinho results showed some stiffening behaviour at large strains. Pinho attributed that behaviour to extrapolation in the lamina stress–strain curves.
The failure stresses ranged from 192.8 MPa (Christensen’s prediction) to 412 MPa (Wolfe’s prediction), giving a ratio between these extreme predictions of 2.13.
A large variation in the failure strains was predicted. For the compressive strains, Christensen predicted a strain of −1.05% whereas Wolfe predicted −6.9%, giving a ratio between them of 6.54. A much larger variation was obtained for the tensile failure strains where the ratio between Wolfe’s and Christensen’s predictions was 24.
Figure 17.
Superimposed theoretical stress–strain curves predicted by the participants of WWFE-II for test case 9. Compressive stress–strain curves for ±35° glass/epoxy laminates under σx = σz = −100 MPa. Top graph: Prediction from six participants. Bottom: Predictions from the other six participants. Figure 18.
Bar charts showing the theoretical predictions of the participants of WWFE-II for test case 9. Top: Compressive strength. Bottom: Compressive failure strain.

sec.title: Test case 10: Failure envelope for (0°/90°/±45°)s carbon/epoxy laminate under combined σz and τzy
sec.p:
In this test case, the laminate was subjected to combined through-thickness direct stress (σz) and shear stress (τzy). The failure envelopes are shown in Figure 19 and a comparison between the failure stresses at key stress ratios are depicted in the bar charts in Figure 20. A number of observations can be made from these figures and from the analysis provided by the participants. These are as follows:
All participants, except Cuntze and Christensen, provided their predictions and, hence, only 10 models are described here.
Six of the models (Rotem, Carrere, Tsai–Ha, Wolfe, Hansen and Huang) predicted initial failure envelopes that were different to the final failure envelopes. These initial envelopes are not shown here. The other provided one envelope describing the final (initial) failure stresses.
All the models, except that of Hansen, predicted closed envelope.
Eight of the 10 models predicted an enhancement in the shear strength due to the application of compressive stress in the through-thickness direction. Rotem and Bogetti did not. However, the location and the magnitude of the predicted peak shear stress vary from one theory to another.
The maximum enhancement (peak shear stress/uniaxial shear stress) was 1.8 and that produced by Huang’s model.
The peak shear stress took place at a compressive stress of −65.7 MPa, for Huang’s model, and at −443.8 MPa, for Hansen’s model. Wolfe’s prediction was at −339 MPa.
None of the models predicted any enhancement in shear strength under tension stresses. However, Hansen’s model predicted a small enhancement in the tension strength, due to the presence of shear.
Figure 19.
Superimposed theoretical failure envelopes predicted by the participants of WWFE-II for test case 10. Failure envelope for IM7/8551-7 quasi-isotropic laminate under combined through-thickness shear and through-thickness direct stress. Top graph: Full envelopes. Bottom graph is an enlarged picture of the right hand side of the top graph. Figure 20.
Bar charts showing the theoretical predictions of the participants of WWFE-II for test case 10. Top: Through-thickness tensile strength. Middle: Through-thickness shear strength. Bottom: Through-thickness compressive strength.

It was noted that the various models predicted different values even for the uniaxial through-thickness strengths (shear, tension and compression). Some of the salient differences between the models are given as follows:
Shear strength: Values of the predicted strength varied from 52.8 MPa (Tsai–Ha’s model) to 114 MPa (Hansen’s model), giving a maximum ratio of 2.15.
Tensile strength: Values of the predicted strength varied from 50.7 MPa (Hashin’s model) to 95 MPa (Tsai–Ha’s model), giving a maximum ratio of 1.87.
Compressive strength: Values of the predicted strength varied from −246 MPa (Bogetti’s model) to −706 MPa (Huang’s model), giving a maximum ratio of 2.87. The prediction from Hansen’s model was not taken into account, due to being an open envelope.

sec.title: Test case 11: Failure envelope for (0°/90°)s carbon/epoxy laminate under combined σz and τzy
sec.p:
In this test case, the laminate was subjected to combined through-thickness direct stress (σz) and shear stress (τzy). The failure envelopes are shown in Figure 21 and a comparison between the failure stresses at key stress ratios are depicted in the bar charts in Figure 22. A number of observations can be made from these figures and from the analysis provided by the participants. These are similar to those made on test case 10 and are listed as follows:
All participants, except Christensen, provided their predictions.
Six of the models (Rotem, Carrere, Tsai–Ha, Wolfe, Hansen and Huang) predicted initial failure envelopes that were different to the final failure envelopes. The other provided one envelope describing the final (initial) failure stresses.
All the models, except that of Hansen, predicted closed envelope. Hansen again predicted an open envelope.
The majority of the models (9 models), except that of Rotem and Bogetti, predicted an enhancement in the shear strength due to the application of compressive stress in the through-thickness direction. However, the location and the magnitude of the predicted peak shear stress varied from one theory to another. The maximum enhancement (peak shear stress/uniaxial shear stress) was 1.8 and that produced by Huang’s model.
The peak shear stress took place at a compressive stress of −74.7 MPa, for Huang’s model, and at −443 MPa, for Hansen’s model.
None of the models predicted any enhancement in the shear strength under tension stresses.
Figure 21.
Superimposed theoretical failure envelopes predicted by the participants of WWFE-II for test case 10. Failure envelope for (0°/90°) IM7/8551-7 laminate under combined through-thickness shear and through-thickness direct stress. Top graph: Full envelopes. Bottom graph is an enlarged picture of the right hand side of the top graph. Figure 22.
Bar charts showing the theoretical predictions of the participants of WWFE-II for test case 11. Top: Through-thickness tensile strength. Middle: Through-thickness shear strength. Bottom: Through-thickness compressive strength.

It was noted that the various models predicted different values even for the uniaxial through-thickness strengths (shear, tension and compression). Some of the salient differences between the models are given as follows:
Shear strength: Values of the predicted strength varied from 49.7 MPa (Cuntze’s model) (which was close to 52.8 MPa from Tsai–Ha’s model) to 122 MPa (Hansen’s model), giving a maximum ratio of 2.45.
Tensile strength: Values of the predicted strength varied from 50.7 MPa (Hashin’s model) to 103.2 MPa (Tsai–Ha’s model), giving a maximum ratio of 2.03.
Compressive strength: Values of the predicted strength varied from −246 MPa (Bogetti’s model) to −706 MPa (Huang’s model), giving a maximum ratio of 2.87. These are the same as those in test case 10. The prediction from Hansen’s model was not taken into account as his model predicted a large strength value.

sec.title: Test case 12: Stress–strain curves for (0°/90°)s carbon/epoxy laminate under compressive through-thickness direction
sec.p:
In this case, the laminate was subjected to a compressive loading σz in the through-thickness direction (where σx = σy = 0). The stress–strain curves are shown in Figure 23 and the bar charts in Figure 24 show a comparison between the final failure stresses and strains obtained from the models. The following observations may be made.
Bogetti did not provide an appropriate stress–strain curve.
All the models, except that of Christensen, showed nonlinear behaviours.
The shapes of the stress–strain curves were similar in some of the predictions, with the following exceptions:
Rotem provided predictions with a few steps and softening behaviours.
Pinho provided a curve exhibiting stiffening behaviour.
Cuntze predicted curves with large nonlinearity.
Hansen provided curves with extremely large failure stress and strains.
The failure stresses ranged from −397.4 MPa (Tsai–Ha’s prediction) to −4173 MPa (Hansen’s prediction), giving a ratio between these extreme predictions of 10.5. The second highest strength was that of Huang, being −706.5 MPa.
A large variation in the failure strains was predicted.
For the compressive strains, Hansen predicted a strain of −40.3% whereas Pinho predicted −3.69%, giving a ratio between them of 10.9. The second largest failure strain was that predicted by Cuntze, being −16.4%.
For the tensile strain (Poisson’s ratio strain), the largest strain was predicted by Hansen (1.99%) and the lowest was predicted by Tsai–Ha (0.162%), giving a ratio between the two of 12.27. The second largest strain was predicted by Rotem (1.24%).
The largest Poisson’s ratio at failure was 0.166 (from Rotem’s model) and the lowest was 0.0223 (from Cuntze’s model) giving a ratio of 7.4 between them.
Figure 23.
Superimposed theoretical stress–strain curves predicted by the participants of WWFE-II for test case 12. Through-thickness compressive stress–strain curves for (0°/90°) IM7/8551 laminate. Top graph: Prediction from five participants. Bottom: Predictions from the other six participants. Figure 24.
Bar charts showing the theoretical predictions of the participants of WWFE-II for test case 12. Top: Through-thickness compressive strength. Middle: Through-thickness ultimate failure strain. Bottom: Secant Poisson’s ratio.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
Theoretical results, predicted by the participants in the failure exercise, have been presented in the form of superimposed failure envelopes, bar charts, and superimposed stress–strain curves for pure resin material, 0°, (0°/±45°/90°)s, (±35°)s and (0°/90°)s laminates. Differences and similarities between the predictions of all the theories for each of the cases analysed have been described. Among the factors that have affected the predicted failure envelopes and stress-strain curves for the laminates are:
Differences in failure criteria applied to isotropic and anisotropic materials.
Differences in the failure criteria applied at the lamina or constituent level.
Allowances made in some theories for the differences in the lamina strength when tested in isolation and when embedded in a laminate.
Inclusion of pressure dependency terms in the constitutive equations.
Inclusion of residual thermal stresses as a result of the curing process.
Type of analysis (linear or nonlinear).
Differences between post failure models and mechanisms.
Ability to account for differences between through-thickness and transverse strength of a UD lamina.
Some of these factors are discussed in more detail below.

sec.title: Differences between through-thickness and transverse strengths
sec.p: The organisers provided the participants with data that showed that, for some composite materials, the direct strength in the through-thickness direction is different to that in the transverse direction. The majority of the models employed were unable to account for differences between the through-thickness and transverse strength values of a UD lamina. The formulation of these models (ie employing transverse isotropy assumptions) did not allow for these differences.

One of the models that showed a peculiar dependency on the through-thickness strength is that of Christensen. The model assumes that the through-thickness shear strength S23 plays a major role in determining the magnitude of biaxial and triaxial failure stresses. This strength is given in terms of the transverse tensile (YT) and transverse compressive (YC) strength where the following condition must be satisfied: S23≥0.5YTYC. The model did not take into account the through-thickness strengths (ZT and ZC). In addition, the data provided by the organisers did not satisfy the above relationship. Consequently, Christensen assumed a convenient value for S23 in order to carry out the analysis. As a result, some of the low compressive strength predictions for some of the test cases were affected by the choice of the value of S23.

sec.title: Differences between failure criteria for isotropic and anisotropic materials
sec.p: In order to assess how the models were used to predict the behaviour of both homogeneous and orthotropic materials, the organisers provided the participants with two key test cases. Test case 1 deals with an isotropic material subjected to a range of triaxial compressive stress states and test case 5 is concerned with a UD lamina subjected to the same conditions. The test cases selected here are important building blocks in our understanding of traditional, high performance, continuous fibre, laminated composites which typically contain 60% fibre volume fraction in order to gain both stiffness and strength.

It is accepted that a number of failure models rely on micromechanics to model the behaviour of the composite starting from that of the constituents, namely fibres and matrix. For this reason, a full understanding of the response of resin matrix is crucial for gaining an insight into how these micromechanics models tackle the behaviour of one of the main constituents of a composite material.

The two cases are interrelated insofar as the epoxy polymer material studied in test case 1 is the same resin matrix used in making the E-glass/epoxy composite laminate in test case 5. Hence, in choosing test cases 1 and 5 these will begin to illuminate the assumptions made in each theory regarding the treatment of material isotropy/anisotropy and material heterogeneity. The mechanical properties are provided in Kaddour and Hinton3 where the epoxy exhibits isotropic stiffness but anisotropic strength properties, with a uniaxial tensile strength that is lower than the uniaxial compressive strength.
As there are many stress combinations that can be applied under 3D loadings, test cases 1 and 5 deal with a section through the 3D space and the state of stress consists of the following:
For case 1: Combined σ2 and σ1 (= σ3): The stresses applied are such that those in 1 and 3 directions are equal while that in 2 direction varies proportional to that in 1 direction.
For case 5: Combined σ2 and σ1 (= σ3): Where σ1 is applied parallel to the fibre direction, σ2 is applied in the through thickness direction and σ3 is applied in the transverse direction.

Figures 2, 9 and 10 show the failure envelopes predicted by different contributors for the two test cases. The predictions share similar features which raise a number of interesting issues regarding the assumptions used in the theories. Table 6 provides a summary of the general shapes of the envelopes. This table is just a sub-section of Table 8. These shapes are categorised as (a) open and (b) closed envelopes. In the last column, the models are described either as seamless or switched, depending upon the types of analysis used.

The theories can also be classified according to the type of analysis used:
Analysis type 1 (seamless models):These theories employ identical equations for both the isotropic material (test case 1) and the anisotropic material (test case 5). These will be referred to as ‘seamless’ models and they include Bogetti’s and Hashin’s models. In one of these models (Hashin’s), the application of the composite criteria to isotropic material resulted in two sets of predictions, depending upon the interpretation of the stresses applied. Based on these two sets of prediction, the innermost (i.e. most conservative) envelope, resulting from the interaction between the two curves, was considered in the present work, as recommended by the participants.
Analysis type 2 (switched models):These theories use different sets of equations, one for the isotropic material (test case 1) and a separate set for the anisotropic material (test case 5 and all the other test cases). These will be referred to as ‘switched’ models. It can be then concluded that the majority of the participants used ‘switched’ models.

sec.title: Differences between failure criteria for failure in a lamina
sec.p: The participants have employed a wide range of failure criteria on a lamina level. In addition, extra terms were introduced to account for the pressure effects on the strength (and occasionally the modulus and the failure strain). Hansen, Rotem, Pinho and Cuntze have used various terms to account for the pressure effects. One of the consequences of doing so is that the lamina strength under triaxial compression was increased and in some instances there was no failure.

In addition, it was noted that some of the participants introduced various forms of cut-offs in the envelopes in the tension-tension space for some test cases (e.g. test cases 1 and 5). These were introduced to indicate the dominance of different modes of failure.

For those models using micromechanics, their results showed noticeably a wide range of predictions that were different to those from other theories. These models include Hansen, Tsai–Ha and Huang. Some of the extreme predictions observed in all the test cases were from these models. For instance, 19 of the 33 cases analysed in Table 7 identified Hansen, Tsai–Ha and Huang models as those giving either highest or lowest predictions.

The use of maximum strain theory (Bogetti’s model) gave different results to all of the other models. In general, the theory produced some of largest predictions under tension–tension–tension stresses (in cases 1, 5–7) and the lowest predictions under compression–compression–compression stresses (cases 1, 2, 5–8). It also gave the lowest prediction for the through-thickness compressive strengths in test cases 10-12.

Similarly, Christensen’s theory gave some of the lowest predictions in test cases 2, 3, 5–8. As the data shown in Table 7, Christensen’s theory gave a total of 12 of the lowest predictions, see column 5. These were the result of the use of a single second order quadratic failure criterion for the matrix and the assumptions made regarding the relationship between the through-thickness shear strength and the transverse tension and compression strength of a lamina. The selection of the value of S23 was seen to be crucially important for the prediction of this theory.

sec.title: Residual thermal stresses due to curing
sec.p: Another major factor that affected the strength prediction of the laminates was thermal stresses. All the participants were aware that residual thermal stresses could arise in composite laminates that were made at elevated temperatures and then cooled to the operating temperature. However, only a few of the contributors attempted to consider the effects of thermal stresses on their predictions.

Those contributors who took thermal stresses into account used conventional laminate theory to calculate the effects of differential thermal contraction between layers. Only Huang allowed for differential contraction between fibres and matrix within a layer.

It was striking that the effects of thermal stresses on the strength and strain predictions were quite considerable where the difference between the strengths with and without residual stresses was up to 100%. Table 9 shows the effects of thermal stresses on the predicted strength and ultimate failure strains for some of the test cases as obtained by some of the participants. Table 9.

The results from Table 9, and from the individual papers of those participants who considered thermal stresses, show the following features:
Thermal stresses can affect the strength and deformation under through-thickness and triaxial stresses in a manner similar to that under in-plane loading.
The effects can be magnified when nonlinear behaviour is employed. For instance, the stress–strain curves in test case 12 are predicted to be nonlinear by some participants, especially in the loading direction:
The results from Puck’s, Christensen’s and Carrere’s models show that the strength of the laminate in test case 12 is reduced by around 10%, due to inclusion of thermal stresses.
The results from the nonlinear analysis of Puck’s and Carrere’s models showed that the failure strain is reduced, due to the inclusion of thermal stresses, by 28%
The results from Huang’s model, which showed smaller nonlinearities, indicated that the strength is dropped by 34% and the failure strain by 14%, due to the inclusion of thermal stresses.

The experimental measured properties of the UD laminae used as input data would include some effects of residual stresses arising during curing but the issue of residual stresses seems to be important and has not been thoroughly addressed in this exercise.
It may be concluded that the effects of thermal stresses could play a role in the correlation between the various predictions.

list-item.p: A comparison has been made between 12 leading theories employed, by their originators (or their supporters) in the WWFE-II for the prediction of 3D strength and deformation response of 12 challenging test cases. The latter involve various isotropic and fibre-reinforced polymer laminates (0°, (0°/±45°/90°)s, (±35°)s and (0°/90°)s laminates) subjected to a range of through-thickness and triaxial loading conditions.

The majority of the eight theories that were employed in WWFE-I received significant revision to cater for the failure prediction under 3D stress states analysed in WWFE-II. It is perhaps a sign that the science has moved on significantly.
No two models gave identical predictions for any of 12 test cases.
There was a lack of consensus regarding the effects of pressure on the elastic constants, strength behaviour and shear stress–stress curves of the composite lamina.
To avoid the complexity of using closed form solutions for the 3D stress analysis of laminates, some participants used finite element codes to obtain the 3D stresses and deformations.

There was a clear tendency among the participants to use micromechanics for the predictions of the test cases. The results of the various micromechanical models showed large divergence, when compared with each other.

The overwhelming majority of theoreticians (9 out of 12) employed separate equations to delineate between isotropic and heterogeneous materials. This appears not to be an opaque feature of the models employed and rather it appears to require a conscious ‘operator intervention’ to make that selection, based on an examination of the problem to be analysed. From a designer’s perspective, the preference would be for the provision of modelling tools with assured resilience that predictions would be accurate in all circumstances without undue (and ideally any) operator intervention).

There was significant diversity between the theoretical predictions in terms of whether or not the envelopes should be open under equal combined compressive through-thickness and transverse stresses and under equal triaxial compressive stresses.

No consensus was achieved on how to predict the nonlinear lamina shear stress–strain curves under high levels of hydrostatic pressure. A variety of methods were employed and the predicted failure shear strain at −600 MPa pressure ranged from 3% to 27% and the shear strength from 50 to 300 MPa.

The models gave a relatively wide range of predictions for the uniaxial through-thickness strengths of the laminates in test cases 10 and 11. Differences in the prediction of the through-thickness tension and through-thickness shear strengths were up to 200% and those in the prediction of through-thickness compression were around 300%.

There was a general consensus among many theories that the application of compressive through-thickness stress leads to an increase in the shear strength of a UD lamina and in the through-thickness shear strength of a multi-directional laminates.

In this article, we have concentrated on drawing attention to differences between the various theories and particularly to differences between their predictions for the selected laminates and biaxial loading cases. The fact that a theory predicts different results from all of the other theories does not necessarily mean that it is incorrect. Any judgements as to which theoretical approach is the best should be suspended until the comparison with experimental results is conducted and commented upon in Part B of WWFE-II.
